column2: Destination Title
column11: Review Text

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column8: You can find both peace and beauty here
column11: If you are visiting Mihintale, make sure to visit this place too. You are coming from the Trincomalee road then you have to pass the Mihintale, and if you are coming from Kandy road you will find it before Mihintale. Best time to enjoy the view would be afternoons.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: We visited with our 1 year old. The road to pond is stoned steps. Can't take wheelchairs and stroller. But it's not far from parking grounds. There are ruins around the area. The pond was built for use of monks. Please kind enough to not to take bath. Aramaya is occupied with 7-8 monks. It is said that this place was used to chant pirith in ancient times. We visited there in the evening. Not a good time as some drunken men come to take baths

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: A calm and peaceful place with a huge ancient pond. The pond is said to be used by the meditating Buddhist monks in the past. Located just 500m away from mihinthale, yet not many people visit this place. Hence the place is very calm and quite. A must visit for sure.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: One of the best to visit. Located in a center of a tea estate. Clear water. Cool weather. Cannot get in to kalu diga pokuna since  it is prohibited by the police. Off rangala road.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: A sacred place with a long history. A calm and quite place. i did not find anyone visiting this place but surely it is a place to visit.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: We visited this place while exploring the ancient city. Amazing irrigation system built during the ancient occupation of this area.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column8: Our visit to Mihinthale and its surrounding ruins and lakes
column11: Mihinthale is a wonderful rock temple that any healthy visitor will enjoy climbing.  There is so much to see and some places you can see ruins of ancient structures remaining without any restorations.  Mihinthale has been a monastry and has been used by the Buddhist monks who used to meditate most of the day and hence engauged in a secular life.  Kalu Diya Pokuna is one of the small lakes used by those monks for fulfilling the water needs and it is a beautiful gift to anybody wanting to have a nice relaxing place to relieve the working stress and fatigue of present day life.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: This is nice area to rest.The old pond is called black pond due to the tree cover of the water body.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Located near to the famous Mihintale monastery . Some people can say this may be a extension of the same monastery. However according to the Archeological evidences this place was awarded to the Buddhist monks by aa army leader of King Kashyapa the 4th. Some says that the name of this historical place was arrived by the color of the water in this pond which was dark due to the darkness of the underground rock or the shades of trees of near by forest.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: This is a small but beautiful place. The lake is man made and is surrounded by large boulders and small archaeology sites that while currently occupied date back 1500 years. The monks live up the hill and meditate in the caves. There is no need to disturb their activity. Just have a wander around the small, ancient structures. Keep your eye out for small details carved in the stone.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: This place is known as "Kalu Diya Pokuna" in Sinhalese and means a black water pond. This is situated in Central Province of Sri Lanka nearby the sacred Buddhist temple, Mihinthale. The surrounded area is known as "Thapo Wanaya" in Sinhalese which means a name for a forest. Even in a forest, there are enough evidences of an ancient palace of a king or of any ruler. In it, there have been three bed rooms, living rooms  and a huge hall. There might have been an ancient king in this place with his wives and the army planning for a war. The appearance of this pond ,provides enough proofs for its name. The tall boundaries around the pond explain it had a huge volume of water in ancient times.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: First impressions weren’t great, with low water and a lot of moss (and it’s clearly a reservoir rather than “natural”) but it turned out to be a beautiful and quiet spot with the attractive reservoir surrounded by ruins. You can take a leisurely walk around the perimeter to see them as well as enjoy the various views.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: This hidden gem of a place should be visited by all those who are interested in organic architecture and landscape. It is such a tranquil place. Not many visitors go there because they are distracted by more famous places in the locality.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: There is very little to see from the road so many people pass this place by without even knowing it's there. We stopped off around lunch time and found a group of about four young men bathing but otherwise we had the place to ourselves. That is until a couple arrived on a motorbike and sat by the water and alternated between gazing into one anothers eyes and into the far distance - love works differently in Sri Lanka. We gave them a wide berth and found a place in the shade to sit and eat our lunch.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: We visited Black Water Lake with our Tuk Tuk driver enroute to climb Mihintale. He told us it was a special Buddhist location and we would like it. He was not wrong, it is an absolute gem. You need to go at the right time (and with the right Tuk Tuk driver) to find the endurance and to be allowed to climb the rocks hidden at the back of the temple ruins to see caves where monks still meditate daily and to see an incredible view without another tourist in sight.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Outside of the bitten track lies this very nice ancient ruins. Situated in the jungle, monkeys and birds all around, almost not a visitor, makes you feel how Anuradhapura erea looks before it was dominated by tourist. A steep small trail leads to the caves where monks are still living today (sometimes it is possible to see them meditate), after the cave there is a window at the cliff from where you can see the vast lands of Anuradhapura: its lakes, forests and stupas tops peeking above it.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Kaludiya Pokuna (Pond of Black Water) About 12 km from main city of Anuradhapura, (an important historical city 200 km north of capital Colombo in Sri Lanka) there is a beautiful suburban town called Mihintale, renowned for most sacred temple known as “Mihintale Temple” which is believed to be a place which gave birth to Buddhism in Sri Lanka when Mahinda met the Sinhale King King Devanampiyatissa in 247 BC, inviting him to accept Buddhism as the island’s state religion. Mahinda was the son of great Mauryan King Asoka. Sinhalese king accepted the invitation and Buddhism soon spread as state religion. Mihintale temple is situated on the top of a hill, led by 1850 steps with seven platforms. These steps are believed to have been laid out during the reign of King Bhathika Abhaya (22 BC–AD 7). Mihintale is studded with many important shrines, stupas, caves, ponds and sacred places. One of such places is called pond of Black Water. It is a very peaceful place for meditation or solitary picnic. The pond is believed to be a source of supply of water to the monastery attached with the temple a thousand years ago. Some ruins of the old monastic structures can still be seen around the lake.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: When we visited there was an abandoned puppy we found there. We actually took her to the vet and gave some worming and lice treatment to the puppy but no one could give her a home so they made us put her back at Black water. Please if you visit take some food to leave there for the dogs as there were at least two young dogs seen there. Otherwise the site is very nice and the monks living there were very friendly.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: We really loved this peaceful place outside Anuradhapura. Beautifully kept. Cool with all the trees. Lots of playful little monkees.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: It's been a once a month travel there when I stayed at Mihintale with my Friend. It is so called as black water-pond because the water color is black due to Algae. It's very calm Quite place when consider to mihintale temple. Please visit there as quietly monks sty near by there. Don't try to bath there it's dangerous. don't lit any thing there.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Very calm and quiet place, and, if you climb the small hill up to the summit (or close enough), you get a superb view of the surroundings. Some ruins can be seen. Be quiet, as there are meditating monks.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Visited this place on my way back from Mihintale. Large water pond that surrounded by an ancient monastery with lost of ancient ruins. Place is situated very close to the A9 main road, but you never feel that when you inside. Very good place to relax or meditation.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: This is one of the best meditation complex you can see in sri lanka if you need to visit the caves and the meditation place you have to go there morning 10.30-12.00

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: An ideal place to refresh your mind and soul in anuradhapura after jaya sri maha bodhiya..such a calming place, beware of monkeys.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: This pond is a little way out of Anuradhapura near to Mahintale and is one of the very many places worth visiting in the area. Named Kalu (which means black in Sinhala), it has dark water which adds to the mysterious atmosphere of the place. It is close to the site of an old monastery and the water would have been used by the monks. The surroundings are tranquil and exude a sense of history and heritage.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Unbelievably beautiful.  A must see. Temple flowers on the ground. So quite and peaceful. You could spend a day exploring. It's pretty big Site.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: The water in the pond  looks black in colour hence the name "Kaludiya Pokuna",(Kalu means black in Sinhala) supposed to be very deep, its closer to Mihintale Stupa, which is a few KM from Anuradhapura. The pond was used by the monks who lived  in caves & temples in the area a few centuries ago.The pond is neglected & not fit  for human use now.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Another one from the series of things to see in Anuradhapura. A natural site in its own words and the water is black at a glance. Looks very pure and soothing. Well worth a visit.

column2: Kalu Diya Pokuna Natural Black Water Pond
column11: Very close to Mihintale, this is a less visited site in Anuradhapura. The basin of the pond is of black rock, giving the water a blue purple if not back colour. The pond is used for bathing by the ascetics who live in the vicinity. Take a few minutes to just sit under a shade and just take in the stillness and beauty of nature from the opposite side of the entrance.
